bibl.title: Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro v. State of Washington. Petition.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the United States District Court in and for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro alias B.K. Sugiurd for a writ of habeas corpus. } No. 2504 Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable Edward E. Cushman, Judge of the above entitled court:
The petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, for a writ of habeas corpus in the above entitled casue respectfully shows, to-wit:

I. That the defendants and each of them are unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of their liberty by Joseph R.H. Joacoby, United States Marshall in and for the Western District of Washington, at the County Jail of King County in the State of Washington within said district, under an alleged, pretended and illegal commitment under process in the above entitled court.

II. That said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint are illegal and in violation of the Constitution of the United States and of the several treasties between the sovereignties of the United States and Japan in this, to-wit: That at Seattle within the district and court aforesaid on or about the 4th day of December 1912, the petitioners were indicted by the Grand Jury sitting in and for said district for an alleged violation of the White Slave Traffic Act, that your said petitioners were charged in that indictment, first, with a consumtated violation of the act itself as the same is set forth in counts one and two thereof, and secondly, with a conspiracy between themselves and the other defendants mentioned herein to violate the said act. That said indictment was number 2347 in the files of the above entitled court and was in words and figures as follows, to wit:
"United States of America Northern Division Western District of Washington } ss. No. 2347
The Grand Jurors of the United States of America, duly expaneled, sworn and charged to enguire within and for the Northern Division of the Western District of Washington, upon their oaths, present:

Count I That heretofore, to-wit on or about the 13th day of August, A.D. 1912, one Albert H. Young, one Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B. K. Sugiuro, one Shotoro Washio, one Kayama Ito and one K. Uneda, did wilfully, unlawfully, and feloniously and knowing transport and cause to be transported, and aid and assist in obtaining transportation for, and in transpoerting in Inter State Commerce, from the city of Seattle in the State and Northern Division of Washington, District of Washington, to San Francisco, in the State of Californi, by means of a certain common carrier engaged in interstate commerce, to wit: by means of the ships of the Pacific Steamship Company, a corporation, a certain women, to-wit: One Hana Sato, for the purpose of prostitution, whereby the said woman Hana Ito was transported in interstate commerce from said city of Seattle, State of Washington, to the said city of San Francisco, in the state of California for the purpose of prostitution; contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided against the peace and dignity of the United States of America.
Count II. And the Grand Jurors aforesaid, upon their oaths aforesaid, do further present:

That heretofore, to-wit on or about the 13th day of August, A.D. 1912, Albert H. Young, Kamasburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito and K. Uneda did wilfully, unlawfully and feloniously, knowingly persuade, induce, entice and coerce, and cause to be persuaded, induced, enticed and coercing, a certian woman, to-wit: Hana Sato, to go from the city of Seattle, in 2
the state of Washington, and in the Northern Division, District of Washington, to the city of San Francisco, in the state of California, in interstate commerce, for the purpose of prostitution, and with the intent and purpose on the part of the said Albert H. Young, Kamasaburo Sujiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito and K., Uneda, that the said women Hana Sato should engage in adn giver herself up to the practice of prostitution, and that the said Albert H. Young, Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito, and K. Uneda, did thereby knowingly cause and did aid and assist in causing said women, Hana Sato, to go and be transported and carried as a passenger in interstate commerce over the steamship line of the said Pacific Coast steamship Company, a corporation, from the city of Seattle, State of Washington to the city of San Francisco, state of California, for the purpose of prostitution; that the said Pacific Coast Steamship Companh is and then and there was, as the said Albert H, Young, Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito, and K. Uneda well know a common carrier engaged in the business of transporting and carrying passengers in interstate commerce from the state of Washington to the state of California, and did act in such capacity in bringing said Hana Sato from said city of Seattlee and state of Washington, to said city San Francisco in the state of California, which is contrary to the form and statutes in such cases made and provided and against the peace and dignity of the United States of America.
Count III. And the grand jurors aforesaid, upon their oaths aforesaid, do further present:

That heretofore, and on or about the 25th day of July, A.D. 1912, one Albert Young, one Kamasburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito and K. Uneda did knowingly, wilfully, wickedly, unlawfully, corruptly and feloniously, conspire, combine, confederate, and agree among themselves, and with divers other persons, whose names are to the grand jurors unknown, and whose names for that reason cannot be herein stated, to commit an offence against the United States, to-wit: that the said Albert H. 3
Young, Kamasburo Sugiuro, alias S.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio Yakama Ito and K. Uneda, then and there knowingly, wilfully, wickedly, and unlawfully, corruptly and feloniously, did conspire, combine, confederate and agree among themselves and with divers other persons, whose names are to the grand jurors unknown, knowingly, wilfully, wickedly, unlawfully and feloniously, to persuade, induce, entice and coerce, and to cause to be persuaded, induced, enticed and coercing and to aid and assist in persuading, inducing, enticing and coercing, and to transport and cause to be transported and to aid and assist in obtaining transportation and transporting a women, to-wit: one Hana Sato to go as a passengar in interstate commerce from the city of Seattle in the state of Washington, to the city of San Francisco, in the state of California, for the purpose of prostitution, and with the intent on the part of the said Albert H. Young, Kamasburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito and K. Uneda, that the said woman Hana Sato should engage in the practice of prostitution.
Count IV. And the grand jurors aforesaid upon their oaths aforesaid do further present:

That during the continuance and in accordance with and in pursuance to and to effect the object of, said conspiracy, the said Albert Young, Kamasaburo Sugiuro,alias B.K. Sugiuro, Shotoro Washio, Kayama Ito and K. Uneda, on or about the 12th day of August A.D. 1912, did go to the ticket office of the Pacific Coast Steamship Company, in the city of Seattle, county of King and state of Washington, and Northern Division of the Western District of Washington, to arrange with the said ticket agent for transportation and ticket from the city of Seattle, Washington to San Francisco, California, on the steamship line of the said Pacific Coast Steamship Company, to be used by one said, Hana Sato, and did then and there purchase and obtain transportation and tickets, whereby the said woman Hana Sato, was transported and carried as a passenger in interstate commerce from the said city of Seattle 4
in the state of Washington, Northern Divison of the Western District of Washington, to the city of San Francisco, in the state of California for the purposes of prostitution, contrary to the form of the statute in such cases made and provided and against the peace and dignity of the United States of America."

III. That thereafter on the 9th day of December, 1912 defendants and each of them entered a plea of not-guilty upon the said indictment; that thereafter on the 25th day of Feburary 1913 in the above entitled court within the district aforesaid a jury was duly and regularly sworn and empaneled in the above entitled cause and the said defendants then and there placed on trial upon the said indictment and their plea of not- guilty thereto; that then and there, after the said jury was sworn, empaneled and charged, and after your said petitioners had been placed on trial is said cause, upon motion of your said petitioners the Government was required by said court to elect upon which two counts it would proceed to prosecute your petitioners, to-wit: That the court required the Government to elect whether it would try the defendants either upon the consumated offense as set forth in the first two counts in the indictment or upon the conspiracy to commit and offense as set forth in the last two counts of said indictment; that thereupon the United States elected to try your petitioners, the defendants in said cause, upon the first two counts of said indictment, to-wit: Upon the counts in said indictment which charged the defendants with the consumated offense under the said act.

IV. That thereafter on the 1st dat of March, 1913, after all the testimony in said cause had been introduced, and after instructions by the court and arguments of counsel the cause was submitted to the jury, and the said jury thereafter on said March 1st having duly considered the evidence, and after due deliberation thereof, returned a verdict of not-guilty as against your petitioner 5
herein.

V. That thereafter on the 5th day of May, 1912, the grand jurors sitting in and for the said court and district returned an indictment in Cause #2471 against your petitioners herein, which indictment is hereafter set forth in words and figures as follows, to-wit: "The United States of America, Northern Division, Western District of Washington. ss No.2471
The grand jurors of the United States of America duly empaneled, sworn and charged to inquire with and for the Northern Division of the Western District of Washington upon their oaths presents:

That heretofore, to-wit: On or about the 25th day of July, 1912, one Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, one Albert E. Young, one Shotaro Washio, one Kyugoro Ito, and one K. Uneda did knowingly, willfullyh, wickedly, unlawfully, corruptly and feloniously conspire, combine, confederate and agree among themselves and with divers other persons whose names are to the grand jurors unknown, and whose names for that reason cannot be herein stated to commit an offense aganist the United States, to-wit: The said Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, Albert H. Young, Shotaro Washio, Kyugoro Ito and K. Uneda then and there knowingly, willfully, wickedly, unlawfully, corrputly and feloniously did conspire, combine, confederate and agree among themselves and with divers other persons whose names are to the grand jurors unknown, knowingly, willfully, wickedly, unlawfully and feloniously to persuade, induce, entice and coerce and to cause to be persuaded, induced, entilted and coercing and to transport and cause to be transported a woman, to-wit: One Hana Sato to go as a passenger in interstate commerce from the city of Seattle in the state of Washington to the city of San Francisco in the state of California for the purpose of prostitution and with the intent on the part 6
of said Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias S.K. Sugiuro, Albert H. Young, Shotaro Washio, Kyugoro Ito and K. Uneda that the said woman Hana Sato should engage in the practice of prostitution.
And the grand jurors aforesaid upon their oaths aforesaid do further present:

That after the formation of said unlawful conspiracy and during continuance thereof and to effect the object thereof the said Albert H. Young on or about the 13th day of August, 1912 in the city of Seattle, county of King, state of Washington and within the Northern Division of the Western District of Washington did purchase from the Pacific Coast Steamship Companym, a corporation, a ticket to be used by himself, the said Albert H. Young, in going as a passenger in interstate commerce over the steamship line of the said company from the said city of Seattle to the said city of San Francisco.
And the gran jurors aforesaid upon their oaths aforesaid do further present:

That after the formation of said unlawful conspiracy and during the continuance thereof, and to effect the object thereof, the said Albert H. Young, on or about the 13th day of August, 1912 did go to the ticket office of the Pacific Coast Steamship Company in the city of Seattle, county of King, state of Washington and in the Northern Division of the Western District of Washington to arrange with said ticket agent for transportation and tickets from the city of Seattle, Washington to San Francisco, California, over the steamship line of the said Pacific Coast Steamship Company, to be used by said Hana Sato and did then and there purchase and obtain transportation and tickets whereby the said woman Hana Sato was transported and carried as a passenger in interstate commerce from the said city of Seattle in the state of Washington and within the Northern Division of the Western District of Washington, to the city of San Francisco in the state of California for the purpose of prostitution.

And the grand jurors aforesaid upon their oaths aforesaid 7
do further present:

That after the formation of said unlawful conspiracy and during the continuance thereof and to effect the object thereof the said Albert H. Young, siad Sugiuro and the said Shotaro Washio did on or abour the 9th day of August, 1912 go from the said city of Seattle to the city of Tacoma in the state of Washington.
And the grand jurors aforesaid upon their oaths aforesaid do further present:

That after the formation of said unlawful conspiracy and during the continuance thereof and to effect the object thereof the said Albert H. Young and the said Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, did on or about the 9th day of August, 1912 in the city of Tacoma, state of Washington, coerce the said Hana Sato to go from teh city of Tacoma to the said city of Seattle; contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided and against the peace and dignity of the United States of America."

VI. That thereafter under the authority and by virtue of the last mentioned indictment your petitioners were arrested by said Marshall and by his brought before the above entitled court and by said above entitled court on said day committed to the county jail to await trial upon said indictment, and that your said petitioners ever since have been and now are in the custody of the said United States Marshall and are detained and imprisoned in the county jail at Seattle, Washington, all as aforesaid. That your petitioners are as aforesaid unduly, illegally and wrongfully imprisoned in the said county jail adn deprived of their liberty, which imprisonment and deprivation of liberty are in violation of the constitution of the United States in this, that your petitioners are being twice put in jeopardy of life or limb for the same offense within the fifth amendment to the United States Constitution; that by reason of the former acquitial of your petitioners upon this said offense your petitioners are as aforesaid illegally 8
detained and imprisoned and for said reason now bring this petition for a writ of habeas corpus in this said cause.

Wherefore, your petitioners pray that a writ of habeas corpus may issue out of and under the seal of this Honorable Court directed to Joseph R.H. Jacoby as the Marshall of the United States in and for the court and district aforesaid, then and there commanding him, the said Jacoby to forthwith bring the bodies of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro, alias B.K. Sugiuro, befoe this Honorable Court as such time as the court may direct, then and there to be dealt with according to law and to abide such decree or order as this Honorable Court may make in the premises.
div1.ab: Albert H. Young Kamasaburo Sugiuro Petitioners.
Walter S. Martin and Robert W. McCelland Attorneys for petitioners.
div1.p: In the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro alias B.K. Sugiuro for a writ of habeas corpus.
Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Filed in teh U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, JUN 19 1913 Frank L. Crosby, Clerk. By EML Deputy.
Robert W. McCelland and , Wardall & Martin Walter S. Martin Attorneys for petitioners
#805 Leary Bldg 540-1-2 New York Block Seattle
District Court of Washington County of King} ss.

Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Suguiro each for himself and not one for the other being first duly sworn on oath says: Yjat he is the petitioner in the above entitled actions: That he has read the foregoing petition knows the contents thereof and the same to be is true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 19th day of June 1913 Walter S. Martin Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, counties of Seattle, Washington.
